Important note: All students will be assigned into groups of three, this group is referred to as your Triad. The first assessment style is called ‘Activity: Knowledge Check’ (you will see the graphic on the left) - this will take the form of ‘interactive questions’ that once you submit your response you will then be provided with feedback in the form of the ‘correct’ answer.


The second assessment style is called ‘Activity: Reflection’ (you will see the graphic on the left) - this is a form of ‘self-development/self-planning/self-understanding’ assessment, we invite you to look at your teaching and your students learning and apply your learning from the content in the badge to your own situation. We will provide a template, which will help guide your reflection and encourage you to include this in your teaching portfolio (e-portfolio) where you continually reflect on and build upon your continuing professional development.


We encourage you to share some of your reflections with peers in a workshop setting or submit them to an on-line forum set up by the badge coordinator when completing the digital badge. Please note that when you fill in the information in the space provided within the learning unit, during the badge, this is visible only to you. If you would like to share it please complete the downloadable word document and submit to the VLE, add it to your e-portfolio or otherwise as suggested by your badge coordinator.
title: Text Title

body:
We are delighted that you have chosen to complete this digital badge on Enhancing Teaching through Interactive Classes to Engage Students. We call it the EnTICE badge, for short, and we really hope you find it beneficial. In this digital badge we seek to increase your awareness of different teaching strategies, with a particular emphasis on active learning. We seek to help you realise that there is often a difference between what you teach and what the students learn and encourage you to adapt strategies that help you recognise what the students have learned. Herein we seek to help you bridge this gap between teaching and learning in your classroom by using active learning strategies, engaging with your students and consistently seeking feedback and checking understanding.


We hope to open you up to new teaching and learning ideas, to ensure your students attain the knowledge and skills you want your students to graduate with. More especially we want to help you to build on your unique personality and become comfortable with a teaching style that ensures a collaborative caring teaching environment that benefits you and your students.
title: Text Title

body: On completion of this digital badge you will be able to:
title: Text Title

instruction: Click the arrow to reveal the learning outcomes

_items.title: 1. Reflect on and document challenges with your own teaching.
2: Outline and critically evaluate effective teaching strategies with a focus on active learning and the advantages of student centered learning.
3: Implement effective teaching strategies and gather feedback through the four lenses of self, peers, students, and the literature.
4: Reflect on and critique your own teaching strategies with a focus on continuous improvement and professional development.

body: On completion of this digital badge you will be able to:
title: Text Title

instruction: Click the arrow to reveal the learning outcomes

_items.title: Reflect on and document a challenging aspect of your own teaching to date
Discuss and evaluate some teaching and learning based case studies​
Develop a reader response and a micro teaching session on any active learning strategy

Implement, reflect and collate feedback (from students, peers, self and literature) on a teaching strategy you used in class to overcome any of the teaching and learning related issues you have identified

Teaching and Learning Unit, MTU Cork


The Teaching and Learning Unit (TLU), Office of Registrar and VP for Academic Affairs, MTU Cork, aims to: 

  • Encourage and facilitate excellence in teaching and learning by providing a range of relevant and accessible professional development opportunities and supports.

  • Enhance learning and development of MTU staff and students.

  • Encourage scholarship, research and innovation in teaching and learning.

Membership of the TLU is currently drawn from each Faculty within MTU Cork.


Activities are varied and include:

  • MA in Teaching and Learning in Higher Education for MTU staff

  • Workshops and courses provided to staff in areas such as instructional and curriculum design, assessment, problem-based learning, and   technology-enhanced learning

  • Staff induction and mentoring

  • Promoting and supporting teaching and learning enhancement and innovation through a university wide Teaching and Learning Development Fund

The TLU is research active, with new teaching and learning approaches and methodologies constantly being piloted and, as appropriate, mainstreamed in the university.


More information can be found on the TLU website.

A personal reflection at the beginning of the course in relation to what you want to achieve from the course and your current philosophy on effective teaching and learning practices. (Please click on the link below to download the template BAC: Self Reflection, Why am I here?) 


Think of something you are really good at (a hobby, sport etc). How did you become really good at it? How do you know you are really good at it? (Please click on the link below to download the template - BAC: What Helped Me Become an Expert?)


Follow and complete the Gibbs Reflective Cycle to reflect on a problem/issue you are having with a current class, F2F or Online. (Please click on the link below to download the template - BAC: Reflecting on My Teaching Practice)


Related to Section on ‘Confidence Building: Learning with and from others’

Watch both Mona Lisa videos and give your perspective on the two ‘Mona Lisa’ sessions using the lens of Bloom's Taxonomy. Continuing to use the lens of Bloom's Taxonomy, complete a deeper reflection on one of your own classes where you felt the session did not go well and one where you felt the session did go well. (Please click on the link below to download the template- BAC:Reflecting Through the Lens of Bloom's Taxonomy)


Related to Section on “Gathering Evidence: Planning and Making Sense of Feedback”

Collect Feedback from a current class, ideally the same class that you identified the problem/issue with before you implement an active learning strategy (Please click on the link below to download an adaptable feedback template - BAC: Feedback from Students (Mid-way in Module/Course))


Related to Section on ‘Professional Development: Introduction to teaching strategies with a focus on Active Learning.

Review a number of Teaching Strategies and Active Learning strategies – write a reader’s response to any paper on the strategy(ies) you wish to implement (Please click on the link below to download an adaptable reader-response template - BAC: Reader Response)


Related to Section on ‘Implementing New Teaching Strategies’

Create a micro lecture incorporating what you have learned, about teaching strategies and an active learning strategy, to solve any issues identified in the feedback or from your personal reflection. This session can be F2F, Online Synchronous or Online Asynchronous.


  • Plan your micro-teaching session (Please click on the link below to download an adaptable planning template - BAC: Plan Micro-Teaching Session)

  • Record the 7 minute micro-lecture and place on the VLE for on-line review by your triad or deliver the 7-minute micro lecture to a minimum of 2 peers in person for F2F on live Online. 

  • Get feedback from 2 peers in your triad on the micro-lecture (Please click on the link below to download an adaptable feedback template - BAC: Feedback on Micro-Teaching Session)

  • Give feedback to 2 peers in your triad on their micro lecture (Please click on the link below to download an adaptable feedback template-BAC: Feedback on Micro-Teaching Session)


Reflect on the feedback obtained from peers on your micro-session and on the lessons you learned from the peer-micro sessions you observed and record alterations you made to your teaching strategy accordingly. (Please click on the link below to download an adaptable ‘analysing feedback’ template BAC:Analysing Feedback)


Consult the checklist to prepare for Peer Observation (Please click on the link below to download an adaptable ‘Peer Observation Checklist’ template. BAC: Checklist to Prepare for Peer Observation)


Plan your live session (Please click on the link below to download an adaptable lesson plan template, which can be applied in planning, F2F, Online Synchronous or Online Asynchronous lessons. BAC: Planning Your Lecture)


Run your live session

  • Ask a peer to attend and complete feedback on an agreed aspect of your lecture – peer observation (Please click on the link below to download an adaptable Peer Observation Feedback F2F/Online Synchronous & Peer Observation Feedback Online Asynchronous template. BAC: Peer Observation Feedback Form (F2F/Online Live - Synchronous) and BAC: Peer Observation Feedback Form (Online Recorded - Asynchronous))

  • Reserve a time for a post observation discussion with your peer observer. (Please click on the link below to download an adaptable ‘Post Observation Discussion’ template. BAC: Guidelines for Discussion Post Observation)
  • Ask your peer observer to complete the Peer Observation Confidentiality Agreement (Please click on the link below to download an adaptable ‘Confidentiality Agreement’, template. BAC: Peer Observation Confidentiality Agreement)
  • Get feedback from the class (Please click on the link below to download an adaptable feedback template - BAC: Feedback from Students (End of Module/Course))
  • Analyse and Make Sense of all feedback obtained from peers and students (Please click on the link below to download an adaptable feedback/reflection template BAC:Analysing Feedback)

_items.body: All participants in this Digital Badge will be assigned into groups of three, this group is referred to as your Triad. While your learning in this Digital Badge will be facilitated by your Badge coordinator, it is the peers in your triad that will provide you with support and feedback and will ultimately sign off to say that you have achieved the badge learning outcomes and have earned the Digital Badge on ‘Teaching Strategies for Interactive, Engaged Classes’. You can complete the assessments and activities as guided by your badge facilitator, either individually, in triads or with the whole group. However, in order to develop your practice, peer feedback is very valuable, discussing and sharing all your assignments with your triads in your e-portfolio is advisable. Also, please remember it is your triad that will sign off that you have successfully completed the required tasks to achieve the digital badge.
_items.title: Who do I work with?
How will I present my final ‘Badge Assignment’?
_items.body: The final required ‘Badge Assignment’ will involve the collection and collation of all the ‘Badge Assignment Components’ and a reflection on your learning journey presented in the form of an e-portfolio. For the purpose of sharing your work for discussion and feedback in your triads we suggest that you use an e-portfolio of your choice If you have a preferred e-portfolio platform already please continue to add to this. If you do not currently have an e-portfolio, the National Forum for the Enhancement of Teaching and Learning in Higher Education have provided useful information to get you started with your e-Portfolio, please see https://www.teachingandlearning.ie/resource/eportfolio-hub/. However, it is important to know that we are happy for you to use any e-portfolio of your choice but please ensure you can share your inputs in your triads so that you can obtain this Digital Badge. Please note: We welcome your innovation and encourage you to express your reflection and learning journey using a variety of genera, including but not limited to, reference to the literature, quotes or snippets from speeches, poetry, songs, short stories, films, documentaries, short video clips, podcasts; using images, sketches, photographs, paintings, art, collages, mind maps, analogies, different scenarios & contexts, videos, podcasts, screencasts, animations, story boards, comic strips, dialogues, storytelling, presentations (PowerPoint, Prezi etc), word documents, posters, pictures and so forth.

body:
In order to earn the EnTICE digital badge you will need to: 

  1. Engage with the material on the course.

  2. Engage with your Peer Triad.

  3. Complete and submit the EnTICE Badge Assignment.

  4. Meet with your peers and through discussion, show evidence that you have met the EnTICE badge criteria.

  5. Encourage your Peers to complete the ‘Badge Verification Form:     Verifying you & your peers have met the EnTICE Badge criteria.


How will I present my final ‘Badge Assignment’?


The final required ‘Badge Assignment’ will involve reflection on your learning journey, and we welcome your innovation in terms of how you present this. You can submit the assignment in any format, including but not limited to:

  • Word document

  • PowerPoint

  • Poster

  • Infographic

  • Video

  • Podcast

  • Animation, 

  • MS Sway Portfolio, etc.


While it is not a compulsory component of the badge, we do recommend that you collect and retain all the activities (reflections and BACs) that you complete in an e-Portfolio so that you can readily reference the material when completing your required EnTICE Badge Assignment. This also has the advantage that you can revisit it if you would like to create or submit a teaching and learning portfolio for an award in the future.


If you already have a preferred e-portfolio platform please continue to add to this. If you are new to the idea of an e-Portfolio, Microsoft Sway is an easy to use and share platform. 


Alternatively, the National Forum for the Enhancement of Teaching and Learning in Higher Education have provided useful information to get you stated with your e-Portfolio, please see ePortfolio Hub - National Forum for the Enhancement of Teaching and Learning in Higher Education.

body:
Before delving into the course, we would like you to take a few minutes to reflect and consider what you would like to achieve by completing this badge on Teaching Strategies for Effective, Interactive Classes. We would also like you to consider what effective teaching and learning looks like to you. An adaptable template for this process is provided in the ‘Further Reading’ section of ‘Resources’ below.


A quote we would like you to take into account and consider as you start this learning journey is “Learning is not a spectator sport. Students do not learn much by just sitting in classes, listening to teachers, memorizing pre-packaged assignments and spitting out answers. They must talk about what they are learning, write about it, relate it to past experiences and apply it to their daily lives. They must make what they learn part of themselves” (Chickering and Gamson, 1987, Seven Principles of Good Practice in Undergraduate Education, Pg 4.)

The Badge Assignment Components (BAC) are ‘adaptable resources’ that participants can choose to use, to facilitate completion of the overall required ‘Badge Assignment’. 


Completing these assignments and activities will help you to build your e-portfolio and have your evidence and reference material in place to complete the final required ‘Badge Assignment’. 


The assignments are outlined below and ‘adaptable resources’ in the form of Word documents are available to provide guidelines on how you might complete them.

In all cases, please click on the link to view the downloadable, adaptable document or complete the activity online as instructed by your Digital Badge Facilitator.

title: Flow Chart Title

displayTitle: Questions to Assist You in Reflecting on and Evaluating Your Practice:
instruction: Please click on each question below to reveal more detail

_items.title: Briefly describe and reflect on your active learning strategy and its implementation.
_items.body:
• You might outline briefly the issue/problem you encountered in your teaching practice 

  • Identify the active learning strategy you considered suitable to address this issue and why you believed it would be beneficial to your students' learning

  • Develop your hypothesis or research question. 

  • Outline briefly how you implemented your active learning strategy. What did you do? What did your students do? 

  • Reflect on the implementation process, what went well and what would you change in a future iteration?

• Discuss when you collected the student feedback (start, middle or end of the course).

  • How did you collect the data? (through a questionnaire, focus group, interview; online, face to face, other)

  • What percentage of the class(es) responded?

  • What were the main positives that you identified from this data?

  • What avenues for development can be identified from this data? 

  • Briefly outline where, when and how peer observation data/feedback was collected?

  • What positives did your peers identify in your practice? 

  • What avenues for development can be identified from the data obtained from your peers? 

  • Are there common themes or interesting differences between the student and peer feedback?
_items.title: Evaluate feedback obtained from peers (micro teaching and peer-observation) and from students identifying commonalities and differences between both.
Show how your findings intersect with the literature related to student centered and active learning
_items.body:
• Have similar studies been conducted elsewhere, briefly describe these studies?

  • How do the themes emerging from your work relate to recommended higher education practices such as active or student-centred learning? 

  • In light of the literature, give brief consideration to any limitations of your findings

• Does this data (student, peer, literature, early personal reflections) suggest to you that your teaching practice should or does need to change? 

  • What, if any, are the more immediate changes that you might have begun to implement already or could envisage implementing next semester?

  • Are there more significant or longer term changes that you would like to make to your practice? 

  • What do you see are the main challenges associated with realizing either change?

  • What are the main enablers / supports in place to enable such changes from your perspective?
_items.title: Discuss the implications of your findings for your practice and identify any changes you can implement immediately and any challenges with implementing changes going forward.
